conclusion: The problem involves a uniform electric field and a positively charged ball moving under electric force and gravity.
Objective is to find the difference in electric potential energy at the highest point compared to point O.
The ball moves in a straight line at an angle θ to the opposite direction of the electric field.
The forces acting on the ball are electric force and gravitational force.
Electric force due to uniform electric field E is constant and horizontal.
The net force acting on the ball must be along the direction of its straight-line path.
Coordinate system defined with horizontal direction as x-axis and vertical direction as y-axis.
Ball moves at an angle θ to the left from the horizontal.
The vector sum of electric force and gravitational force is along the direction of the velocity.
Electric force Fe acts to the left, gravitational force Fg acts downward.
Net force Fnet is the sum of Fe and Fg, and should be along the direction of velocity.
Net force components: Fe = -qE i, Fg = -mg j.
Net force Fnet = F (cos θ i + sin θ j), where F is the magnitude of net force.
Equating components: -qE = F cos θ and -mg = F sin θ.
Solve for F: F = -qE / cos θ = -mg / sin θ.
